body.p:
My dear friends & sisters
When I offered to tell you
something of Revd Isaac Leeser
I imagined it would be an
easy task to describe a man of
such strong personalities who had
been one of the central figures
connected with my early youth &
womanhood to whom next to my
own Father I owe every noble thought
and the love of good books; which
he helped guided & cheered me through
all the vicisitudes of a long life

His labors in Instruction &
Philanthropy would fill a
volume.

It was largely owing to his efforts
that the Maimonides College was
opened in Phila. Oct 1867. He was
1st Provost of its faculty, teaching
Homilelics_Belle Letters_Theology &c
From This first attempt at a
Jewish Seminary languished
After years of a struggling existance
but through the efforts of Doctor Sabato
Morais was transferred to New York
City principally for pecuniary
reasons & called the Jewish Theological
Seminary College. How its first founder
would rejoin could he know (and
let us hope? that he does) that D Scheichter
the most learned Prof of the Univ of Camb-England
over comes next May to fill his vacant chair

The request for the Gratz College
was no doubt though not so expressed
intended to further this undertaking
& let us hope will eventually be joined to it
certainly it is much to be regretted
that there should be so many
Jewish Theological Colleges. When
we have so much to contend with
from without why should we
be divided among ourselves to
the weakening of the cause of
Israels God and His worship.

Isaac very early developed the love of learning
the insatiable thirst for information that always characterized
him
began the study of Hebrew
when, almost an infant, for at
the age five years he could read it with ease
and what was very unusual
for Jewish boys in those days & that country
he learned to read German almost
at the same time so that
long before he attained his
religious majority (at thirteen)
he had become a student of
the College at Munster Prussia
where he graduated with high
honors. When sixteen years of age

Unfortunately both his hard
working & loving Parents died
while he was at College and the
young family was divided scattered among
relatives as poor as themselves.
After two years of a rather wandering
life teaching, what he had ac
quired, to those even younger than
himself and receiving in return
sometimes only food & shelter, at
others as small pittance, that was
always spent upon increasing
his small little stock of books & storing
up more facts seeds of knowledge in his wonderful
memory that which were to bear fruit
& plant vinyards
and flourish in a far off country al-
most unknown to the inhabit
ants of the small Prussian Village

His mother's brother Zalma
Reheine ZALMA REHEINE had gone emigrated to America
some years before, and settled
in Richmond Va. Hearing
of the death of his Sister, and
her Husband, he with the ever
characteristic Jewish spirit
of helping the poorer brother
wrote for Isaac to come join
him in the new World across
the Atlantic, which opened
her arms to welcome Jew & Gentile
alike. In M

In May 1824 when Isaac
Leeser was not yet eighteen (18)
years old he arrived in Richmond
an awkward, thickset, German
youth, unable to speak a word
of English & a perfect stranger to all

the habits & customs of the people
among whom he came to dwell.
His uncle Mr Reheine kept a store; in
which his young nephew soon
learned to make himself use
ful in many ways. After opening, sweeping
& arrainging it for the day, he was
at first allowed to attend school
in order to learn to read & write
English; which he acquired with
wonderful rapidity, making for
himself cruid candles 'dips' but of any
thing he could save from the store
Reeds, hemp, cotton waste with
fat or oil of any kind. (Electricity
Gas & Kerosine were then undiscovered)
He litterally burnt the midnight oil
in his little garret, & wake refreshed
for new labors

There was already in Richd
the nucleus of a congregation presided
over by Revd Isaac B. Seixas. Mr Rehine'
store seems to have been a meeting
place for its members & in the discussion
of subjects dear to every Israelite
the young Isaac soon took his full
share generously helping Mr Seixas
in teaching Hebrew & otherwise per
forming the many duties of his office
Jews & Judaism from that time
till the day of his death his labors
were unceasing for the cause
which he then espoused. To him
his pen, his brain & more than
all the inspirations of his lifes
the Jews must ever owe the deepest
debt of gratitude, no one more in
this or any other country has left

He was soon attracted by the
unusual gifts of the young German
whom he encouraged by advice
assistance of every kind ?

four (4) years after landing in
this country in 1828 Isaac Leeser first
attracted public attention by
assailing refuting with great force in the Richd Daily press
an article published in the “London
Quarterly Review,” assailing the
Jews & Judaism. From that time
till the day of his death his labors
were unceasing for the cause
which he then espoused. To him
his pen, his brain, & more than
all the inspirations of his lifes
the Jews must ever owe the deepest
debt of gratitude. No one man in this or any other country has left

them such a legacy. He was
destined never to enjoy the delights
of a home ? nor the Love of
wife or children but he has left
us the labor of Love of a lifetime
P His writings if piled together
would make a monument higher
than we could reach and the
capstone is an English translation
of our own Scriptures that we can
put into the hands of our children
without pasting over the heads of
Chapters as our from their most
tender years to read & reread till
every word is impressed with letters
of gold upon their hearts, to be
an ever present stay in time of
trouble & distress. To be ever on their
lips to refute charges against our Holy Faith

The King James Bible written
by eminent scholars, at a time when
Shakespere Byron Willow Pope & Dryden
had raised the ancient Language
of Chaucer & Spenser to its higher
point
stage of imagry & ?, is
one of the our most equisite
clasics, but in many instances
correctness was sacrificed to
beauty of expression and in
other passages sentences were
almost unconsciously distorted
into non Jewish chanels. Then
the headings of the chapters &
pages, foot notes &c were all
objectionable. So that a purely
Jewish translation of the Holy
Scriptures was hailed with
delight and has become

What Mr Leeser meant that
it could a part of every Jewish
home & place of worship & school.

Though the slight verbal
changes grated upon the ears
of us of the older generation, the
constant reading & reciting
from it in Sunday schools
has made it familiar to the young
and every one must be struck
with the amount of labor accom
plished by one man, almost
entirely unassisted.

I might quote numerous lines texts
in which the sense is entirely
changed or improved one strikes
me very often. Psalm 90 X C Ver 3
“Thou turnest man to contrition &
sayeth return ye children of men”

formerly read, Thou turnest man
to distinction &c.

Dr Weir Mitchell whom
you all know of as the author
of Hugh Wynn is also a Bible
student. He said in a public
lecture in Phila “When I want
to get at the true meaning of
the Psalms and Prophets I go
to my friend Revd Isaac Leeser's
translation as the most satisfying.”
And should we Jews and members
of the Council of Jewish Women
teach to non Jews the study of
those Scriptures which it is our
special most sacred duty to
preserve to keep and to teach
not only to our own children; but to
all the nations of the Earth!?

Oh my dear Sisters if I could
only make those of you who are
unfamiliar with our Scriptures
turn to its pages & read in every
verse new beauties, you would
find it more interesting & more
satisfying than any Romance
To use one of Mr Leeser's many beautiful similies
“It is like a beautiful thing of
rich & rare jewels, each gem perfect in
itself, united by the thread of
Faith makes a perfect complete chain.”

*Encouraging him In 1829 to Mr Leeser accepted
the duties of Hazan of the Congregation
Mickveh Israel of Phila one of
the oldest & then perhaps the
most prominent Jewish Congregations
in the United States, a very
responsible position for a young
man of (23) twenty three who had
been scarcely five years in America
He began the regular duties of his office ? 5590

Though a German Mr Leeser
seems always to have preferred
the Portuguese Ritual and
as early as June 2 1830 he began the in
ovation of adding an English
discourse to the weekly Service
in the Old Cherry St Synagogue
of which he was Hazan until
the Feast of Tabernacles 1850.
*For three years at a salary of $800.

after many reelections for different
periods in 1850 he requested to be
appointed “for life” which being
refused he resigned his position &
severed all connections with the
congregation.

Seven years later some of his
ardent admirers formed a new orthodox
Congregation in Phila. Beth El Emet
of which he remained Hazan
until his Death.

These sermons were at first
written & read, then committed
to memory, but in later years
particularly when he was Hazan of in the Beth-El
synagogue (after 1857) he spoke without
notes of any kind. These extem
poraneous discourses seemed
often to be inspired & ?
who have not heard it is
impossible for me to make
you anyone who had not the great
privilege of hearing them, understand
their full force. His It was no thing
of platitudes, wonderful similes & strong but earnest, helpful
words taken from the Scriptures.
or suggested by their Orthodoxy in

body.p:
I never heard such flow of language
or rapidity of utterance except from
the late lamented Bishop Phillips
Brooks, whose sermons were written
and like him, he riveted your
closest attention, and always left
some new idea for future thought.

Mr Leeser's learning was by no
means confined to the Bible and
sacred subjects. He was not even a
deep student of the Talmud, but
he knew History Fiction & Human
nature thoroughly and was ever
ready to impart his knowledge
every no subject from the fit of a lady's
dress to the most obstruce problem
of Science or Philosophy called forth
his ready chrilecism? or wonderful memory.

Reform with its Hydra-heads
had only just recently appeared in
Charleston S. C. to startle arouse the
spread alarm in the breasts of the old
Orthodox Jews. Mr Leeser & his
successor Revd Sabato Morais
cut off many an infant head
But the contagion monster was
not conquered, & only taught
new fields in the South & West
until grown to its full strength
it attacked the Synagogues
of the East demolished the
women's gallery tore the (Talith)
Prayer scarf from the shoulders
of the men & forbid them to
mount the steps of the (Tebah)
Reading desk & follow the reading
from the Law Turning the

a new Synagogue into a modern
place of worship with Organ
and Choir making as
complete a separation be
tween the factions as did
“Jereboham the son of Kebal”
Whether ? like Hercules Mr Leeser
could have, thrust the fatal
dart, or been able to forsee
that in Union there is strength
and make such concessions
as would write the conflicting
factions must be a matter of
speculation, for though he for
saw the decline of the Portuguese
Ritual & the laxity of its observers,
he hoped much from the German
Jews who were rapidly increasing
in members and influence

P? He was a great admirer of women
Their personal beauty attracted
him, & he was always willing to
grant them all privileges—not
then always allowed by the sterner
sex. I feel sure that he would
have encouraged “the Council
of Jewish Women” in their efforts
for Faith & Humanity—for he
Edited Miss Grace Aguilars “Jewish
Faith” & her 'Spirit of Judaism' and
Hannah Rothschilds ' Prayers & Med-
itations'. And the names of many
women appeared in the pages of
the Occident, first Jewish
Monthly Periodical, which he edited
first in 1843, and carried through
25 years of successful publication
(Leaving it as a legacy to Hon M? Sulzberger)

Though he had only spent a
few years of his early manhood
in the South when the un-
fortunate Civil War broke out
his sympathies all went out
so strongly to the weaker side
that the struggle shortened
his life. I will remember being
with him “Sedar? night' April 2 1860
at the house of a mutual friend
when the boys called, through the that
the 'Surrender of Genl Lee'.

Mr Leeser was so overcome that
he had to stop the Service and
walked home with me almost
without speaking the strongest
possible sign of emotion.

He projected the Union of all
Jewish Charitable organizations
of Phila_which was brought about
after his death in the United
Hebrew Charities and has lately
been cemented by a stronger union.
Indeed there was no project of
his day for the bettering of the
Human Race and the glory
of Judaism that he did not
enter in heart & soul.

He was much respected by learned
men of all persuasions and entered
into many controversies with them
always in the most liberal spirit
and with the greatest consideration
for the difference of Faith.
